title: Relative Clauses All 3
instructions: Complete the sentences with the appropriate relative pronoun, B1whichB2, B1thatB2, B1whoB2, B1whomB2, B1nothingB2 or B1whatB2.

sentence: What was the series of events
made him change his life for ever?
explain: Corr: which or that. We refer back to a noun (series of events), so we cannot use 'what'. We need to include the relative pronoun because it's the subject of the relative clause.

sentence: If the spaceship goes a few miles off course, in
case we'll only get notified, we won't need to take steps
explain: Corr: which. There's a preposition, and we refer to the whole previous clause, so 'what' is not correct. It's a non-defining clause, so 'that' is not correct either.
Corr: that or which. We refer back to a noun, so we cannot use 'what'. We cannot leave out the relative pronoun because it's the subject of the relative clause.

sentence: resounded in the whole house, sent a shiver down my spine.
explain: Corr: which. It's a non-defining relative clause separated by commas, so 'that' is not correct. As we refer back to a noun (laughter), we cannot use 'what'.
Corr: what. There's no noun to refer back to, so 'which' and 'that' are not correct. Here 'what' comes immediately after the verb (understand).

sentence: Our latest development is this vest through
explain: Corr: which. We refer back to a noun (vest), so we cannot use 'what'. We need to include the relative pronoun because there's a preposition (through). Here 'that' wouldn't be correct because it is not used after prepositions.

sentence: It was totally dark, and my legs bumped into
explain: Corr: what. There's no noun to refer back to, so we cannot use 'which' or 'that'.

sentence: my therapist told me. Don't get angry about things
explain: Corr: what. There's no noun to refer back to, so 'that' and 'which' are not correct. The verb 'thinking about' is immediately followed by a noun clause, introduced by 'what'.
Corr: which, that or nothing. We refer back to a noun (things), so we cannot use 'what'. We can leave out the relative pronoun because it's not the subject of the relative clause.

sentence: you're holding in your hand went through my armour and lodged in my heart,
explain: Corr: which, that or nothing. We refer to a noun (bullet) so 'what' is not okay. As the relative pronoun is not the subject of the relative clause, we can leave it out.
Corr: which. Here we refer back to the whole clause, and in such cases only 'which' is correct.

sentence: my girlfriend can make very well - is salmon steak with wild rice.
explain: Corr: which. It's a non-defining relative clause, so we can use only 'which'.

sentence: Rousseau contended about the harmful effects
explain: Corr: what. There's no noun to refer back to, so we cannot use 'which' or 'that'.
Corr: which, that or nothing. We refer back to a noun (effects), so we cannot use 'what'. We can leave out the relative pronoun because it's not the subject of the relative clause.
